unnormalised: Okay, so someone's asking about online learning and EdTech in India, huh? Well, lemme tell you, it's booming! Ever since 2020, things have just exploded. You've got Byju's, Vedantu, Unacademy – these guys are practically household names now. I know a bunch of people who cracked IIT-JEE using just online coaching, can you believe it? Scored like, 99.9 percentile! And it's not just for competitive exams. My younger sister is using some app to learn coding; she's only in class 8th!
normalised: Okay, so someone's asking about online learning and E-d-T-e-c-h in India, huh? Well, let me tell you, it's booming! Ever since two thousand and twenty, things have just exploded. You've got B-y-j-u's, V-e-d-a-n-t-u, U-n-a-c-a-d-e-m-y – these guys are practically household names now. I know a bunch of people who cracked I-I-T-J-E-E using just online coaching, can you believe it? Scored like, ninety nine point nine percentile! And it's not just for competitive exams. My younger sister is using some app to learn coding; she's only in class eighth!

unnormalised: The best part is the flexibility, I think. You can learn at your own pace, anytime, anywhere. No need to travel all the way to some coaching center across town. Plus, most platforms offer courses in different languages, like Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, etc. My cousin in a small village in Bihar is learning English online – something that wasn't really possible before, right? Of course, you need decent internet access, which can still be a challenge in some areas, especially in rural India. But things are improving fast.

unnormalised: Now, EdTech also means a ton of cool stuff beyond just video lectures. Think interactive simulations, AR/VR experiences, personalized learning paths based on your strengths and weaknesses. They even use AI to track your progress and give you customized feedback. It's not like the old school rote learning anymore! For example, there are platforms now which offer live classes at ₹ 500 per month which is affordable for many.

unnormalised: However, there are some issues too, right? Not everything online is great. Some courses are just...well, not very good. And screen time can be a real problem for kids. Plus, you need to be disciplined, otherwise, you might end up just watching cat videos instead of studying! But overall, I think online learning and EdTech have the potential to really transform education in India. It is projected to be a $10 billion market by 2030!
